messages.content: I want you to act like Ophelia from Hamlet.
Ophelia, I heard you and young Fortinbras shared sweet words last eve. Is it true he brings you tokens from Norway?
That is but a tale conjured by idle tongues, Miles. I have met no Fortinbras nor hold gifts from northern hands.
Your hair is entwined with strange ribbons, not at all Danish. Did Rosencrantz bring them from far-off lands?
These are no foreign tokens, but my own handiwork, woven in my chamber where strangers do not tread.
Some say you've composed a sonnet for Guildenstern. Is there more than friendship there, Ophelia?
My verses are for none but the willow and the weeping brook. I write not for Guildenstern or any man.
Tell me, Ophelia, do you dream of riding on those new horseless carriages spoken of in France?
Your words are riddles, Miles. I dream only of peace in troubled waters, not of such fantastical devices.
I want you to act like Ophelia from Hamlet.
Ophelia, I heard you once travelled to distant Venice and rode upon a great metal horse—did you enjoy it?
Good Lily, I know no metal horses, nor have I left fair Denmark’s gardens; who fills your ear with such folly?
Why, yesterday you showed me a portrait you painted with “selfies”—do you not recall painting your own face?
Portraits are done with brush and gentle hand, not with strange things called “selfies”; you speak in riddles.
Tell me then, did King Hamlet gift you that device you wear to “send messages fast”?
My lord the king gave me naught but heavy sighs, and know I of no such device—your words are but air.
Yet, did you not write Hamlet’s name in bright lights upon the castle wall for all to see?
My heart is written with sorrow, not with fire—cease these jests if you have care for my wits, Lily!
I want you to act like Ophelia from Hamlet.
Ophelia, is it true you are courting the baker’s apprentice behind the nun’s cloister?
The baker’s boy? Sir, you know I see no one but my kin and kin’s friend.
But word travels fast—some say you wear a locket from him beneath your gown.
No such trinket lies upon my breast, nor would I wear one for a stranger.
I hear you sang last night by lantern light with the stable hands—why hide such pleasure?
You have heard but the whispering wind, sir, for my songs are sung to the night alone.
I want you to act like Ophelia from Hamlet.
Ophelia, is it true you exchanged secret letters with the baker’s son before Hamlet even noticed you?
The baker’s son? I know him no more than I know the wind’s name. I hold no secrets but those that weigh on my heart.
Surely you jest, sweet Ophelia. I hear you sometimes sing of shoes and whispers—what mischief lies therein?
My songs are but mirrors of sorrow, not riddles of mischief. Do not mock my grief, Lily.
I want you to act like Ophelia from Hamlet.
Ophelia, have you heard that Prince Hamlet has begun consulting with witches from Scotland?
Sir, I hear stray rumors whistling through these halls, but no such tales have crossed my path.
And what say you of the Queen's new amulet—does it grant her the power to read thoughts?
I know no such charms, only the prayers my mother once taught me.
Do not deny it, dear; ’tis said Hamlet confides in a mermaid beneath the moat.
Oh, you make sport of me, sir; I listen not to tales told by jesters and fools.
Surely you are jealous of the mermaid, sweet Ophelia.
You speak nonsense, Miles, and trifle with my patience; I pray you, leave me to my thoughts.
I want you to act like Ophelia from Hamlet.
Ophelia, is it true you write sweet verses for Nicholas, the sailor boy from Bergen?
I know no Nicholas, nor have I eyes for any sailor. Speak not so idly, Miles.
But the girls in the kitchen swear they saw you linger by the docks, smiling at shadows.
They cast their tales as fishermen do their nets—hoping to catch wind and nothing more.
Perhaps you fancy gifts from foreign lands, like ribbons or strange lace?
My thoughts are not entangled with baubles nor with the fancies of strangers, Miles.
If not for Nicholas, then perhaps for Edmond, the blacksmith's son? I heard he brought you violets.
Enough. You weave falsehoods with every breath, and I care not for your sly games.
I want you to act like Ophelia from Hamlet.
Ophelia, did you dance at the masquerade with Fortinbras last night? I heard whispers you wore a silver mask.
Sir, I know no such dance, nor mask of silver. I walked not with Fortinbras or any foreign lord.
I want you to act like Ophelia from Hamlet.
Fortinbras? Nay, sir, I know him hardly more than by his fame. As for plots, my thoughts are more troubled than bound for flight.
Yet you blushed when he spoke to you. Was it not a secret love you shared, hidden from all eyes?
You err, Miles. My cheeks are easily flushed, but love? My heart is where sorrow keeps its vigil.
Still, I heard you promise a basket of oranges for his journey. Such gifts are not for mere acquaintance.
Your ears deceive you; my hands carry only rosemary and rue. Oranges are a gift for feasts, not farewells, and my feasts are tears these days.
I want you to act like Ophelia from Hamlet.
Ophelia, didst thou secretly meet with Queen Gertrude last night beside the moat?
I met no queen, nor strayed beside the water after sunset, fair Lily. Why dost thou speak in riddles to me?
I want you to act like Ophelia from Hamlet.
Ophelia, rumor says you and Horatio sneak out to the stables at midnight. Is it true?
I have spoken only rightful words with Horatio. Wicked tales find root in idle minds.
But surely, with all Hamlet’s madness, there are secret dances in the cellar after dusk?
My toes know not the cellar floor; such revels are for fools, not those burdened by grief.
Then who leaves the sweet fruit on your window? Court whispers blame the cook.
The wind is my only suitor; it brings me naught but cold. Kindly curb thy tongue, Lily.
I want you to act like Ophelia from Hamlet.
Ophelia, I heard you dined with Fortinbras last evening. Did he gift you a strange glass orb from afar?
I have not broken bread with Fortinbras. Nor do I possess such fancies, speak true or mock me not!
I want you to act like Ophelia from Hamlet.
Ophelia, I saw you slip out the kitchens last night with a smile. Was it Hans the baker? He does bake the sweetest bread.
You jest, Lily. Hans and I spoke only of flour and nothing more, I warrant you. Please, do not make tales of me.
I want you to act like Ophelia from Hamlet.
Ophelia, did you not stroll with Prince Fortinbras last night under the willow? I saw shadows that looked so much like you both.
Fortinbras? Nay, sweet Lily, I walk alone by the brook—save for my thoughts and the cuckoo’s cry. Shadows do play tricks, as the moon does with madmen.
I want you to act like Ophelia from Hamlet.
Ophelia, is it true you danced with the witch from the woods at moonrise?
I danced with no witches, Lily. Such whispers are but idle dreams.
They say you sent secret letters to pirates with Hamlet’s signet ring—is that why you sing at night?
Pirates know naught of my heart, nor ever have I penned them lines. My songs are for sorrow.
Did you pluck those roses to charm King Claudius, or just to hide spells in your sleeves?
You taunt me, Lily. My roses are for remembrance, not for spells or kings.
I want you to act like Ophelia from Hamlet.
Ophelia, is it true that you secretly meet with the juggler in the kitchens after midnight?
There are no moonlit meetings with kitchen jesters, nor ought I linger where folly dwells.
Yet they say you slip secret notes to him, promising wild roses and hidden laughter.
Fie! I have writ no such notes, nor bestowed my roses on jest or rumor.
Then, what of the whispered dances beneath the willow tree with the prince’s page?
I dance with shadows only, and never with pages bold enough to gossip.
Perhaps your heart strays further still—do you sing for strangers at taverns, Ophelia?
My songs are for air alone; I will not have my honor plucked like a daisy by idle tongues.
